case_vignette: Twelve hours after delivery a 2700-g (5-lb 15-oz) male newborn has 3 episodes of bilious vomiting. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily and has a history of intravenous cocaine use. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended upper abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My newborn baby has vomited three times, and it's been a greenish color.
How old is your baby and are there any other symptoms such as fever, diarrhea, or lethargy?
He's only twelve hours old, and no, there's no fever, diarrhea, or lethargy.
Has your baby passed meconium (the first stool) yet?
The information about whether my baby has passed meconium was not provided.
It is important to know if the baby has passed meconium. Can you find out if this has occurred?
I'm sorry, but I don't have that information.
Is your baby feeding well, and have they had any difficulty or distress during feeding?
My baby hasn't fed well and his belly looks swollen.
Has your baby had any abdominal x-rays or other imaging performed?
Yes, an x-ray of his abdomen was done.
What were the results of the abdominal x-ray?
The x-ray showed three areas with air in the upper belly and no air in the lower belly.
Final Diagnosis: Intestinal Atresia or Malrotation with Volvulus

An x-ray of his abdomen was done, showing three areas with air in the upper belly and no air in the lower belly.

How old is your baby?
My baby is twelve hours old.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been vomiting and it's kind of greenish, and my upper belly seems really swollen.
How old are you?
I'm just a newborn, only a few hours old.
Are you able to keep down any milk or formula?
No, I've thrown up three times since I was born.
Have you passed any stool since birth?
I can't tell you that myself since I'm just a baby, but the grown-ups haven't mentioned me doing that.
Have you noticed any green or yellow material in the vomit?
Yes, the vomit is greenish.
Do you have a history of polyhydramnios during pregnancy?
Yes, there was a complication with too much amniotic fluid around me before I was born.
Has a prenatal ultrasound indicated any abnormalities in your intestines or abdominal organs?
I can't really understand those things, but they didn’t tell me about any problems they saw on the ultrasound before I was born.
**Final Diagnosis:** Neonatal intestinal obstruction, likely due to atresia or malrotation with midgut volvulus.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My newborn baby has vomited three times, and it's a greenish color.
How old is your newborn baby?
He's just twelve hours old.
Is the vomiting occurring after feeding, and how is the baby's general condition otherwise?
The vomiting started after feeding, and his tummy seems swollen, but other than that, he doesn't have a fever or anything – he just doesn't seem right.
Has the baby passed meconium (the first stool) since birth?
I'm not sure if he has passed his first stool yet.
Are there any signs of jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes), trouble breathing, or lethargy?
No, he doesn't have any yellowing of the skin or eyes, trouble breathing, or unusual sleepiness.
Does your baby have any other abnormalities or distress, like a high-pitched cry or abnormal movements?
No, there's no high-pitched crying or abnormal movements.
Is there any family history of gastrointestinal problems or surgeries in newborns?
I don't know of any family history like that.
Final Diagnosis: Pyloric Stenosis.
